Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Design Methodology for Bio-Inspired Soft Mechanical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will pioneer a systematic synthesis, analysis and manufacturing framework to realize soft mechanical systems. Soft mechanical systems are static and dynamic structural embodiments that do not contain rigid components made of metals or plastics, conventional actuators such as motors, or interfaces such as joints and couplings. They are instead made up of stretchable skins, tissue-like appendages, fibers and fluids, and are inspired by around 90% of nature's animal species that lack a rigid backbone, such as an octopus arm. The unique feature of these systems is that they are flexible yet strong enough to bear large loads. Unfortunately, these systems have so far not been widely used, because a systematic design framework that can guide their physical realization does currently not exist. This award supports fundamental research that enables such a design framework, in which a soft mechanical system can be synthesized through a systematic combination of simple building blocks with pre-determined attributes. The resulting devices are adaptive, lightweight, energy-efficient and inherently safe for human interaction. They will directly impact the emerging fields of rehabilitation robotics, manufacturing automation, space exploration, and surgery. Furthermore, the award will build on the overarching theme of drawing analogies between nature and engineering to increase creative thinking and enhance problem solving abilities in future engineers, while emphasizing broadening participation of underrepresented groups in research.

The key challenge in formulating a generalized design framework for soft mechanical systems involves negotiating the coupled nonlinear interactions among its structural constituents, namely, fluids, stretchable envelopes, and reinforced fibers. The design framework relies on reduced order models to capture these interactions and characterize the kinematic and kinemato-static behavior of a generalized soft mechanical building block. The models can be extended to any structure or mechanism under quasistatic interaction with enclosed fluids. Using these models, a design framework will be developed to synthesize a system, where several building blocks with varying attributes are combined in a series or parallel architecture based on rules and guidelines adapted from traditional machine design, such as constraint matching and geometrically exact kinematics. The design framework will also incorporate optimization methods to refine the system based on novel robustness metrics. Successful realization of the design framework will lead to a reconfigurable stiffness system for use in orthotic braces and a self-knotting active rope for use in surgical suturing and active tethering applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over 90% of wildlife lack a hard skeleton, and are yet strong, showcase adaptive locomotion and dexterous manipulation. Soft mechanical systems are the engineering translation of nature?s designs and have resulted in recent advances in soft active materials, sensors, controls, and their manufacturing technologies. However, these advances have leapfrogged beyond the ability of traditional design methods to fully exploit their potential. The research goals of this award were to build a systematic design framework for soft mechanical systems towards a given motion (kinematic) and force (kinetostatic) requirement. The approach investigated in the proposal is the building block method, where a fundamental bioinspired building block known as fiber reinforced elastomeric enclosure (FREE) was identified, and parametrically studied. FREEs consist of a hollow elastomeric cylinder wound by two interlaced families of fibers, whose orientation determine the deformation kinematics. Soft mechanical systems are envisaged as a system combination of several FREEs, each with specific fiber orientations. Two design problems were solved (i) design of fiber orientations for the FREE to reach a specific deformed spatial trajectory using a formulation based on calculus of variation, (ii) design of networked architecture of FREEs to yield a specific force and motion requirement using pseudo-rigid body models. Furthermore, the idea of soft mechanical systems was expanded to include passive mechanical metamaterials, whose microstructure geometries can be tuned to affect a global deformation behavior. Specifically, a qualitative classification scheme for metamaterial building blocks based on shear modulus and Poisson?s ratio was proposed. This limits the design space of metamaterials into four qualitative regions, thus making the global design problem conceptually tractable. A homogenization-based method was explored to design a shape-adaptive structure as a combination of the different building-block classes. User interactivity of spatial designs were enhanced by a virtual reality framework.

The fundamental investigations in the design process of soft systems led to several novel robotic solutions in healthcare and agriculture. Specifically, a wearable stiffness sleeve to improve the load bearing ability of the upper extremities were investigated using a novel architecture of miniaturized FREEs. Furthermore, a novel compact and dexterous manipulator using parallel combination of asymmetric FREEs was developed for agricultural berry harvesting. The educational prat of the project led to two activities: (i) a freshman orientation course for industrial and systems engineers through a combination of design and robotics projects, (ii) a high school activity to introduce robotics terminologies through soft robotics projects and demonstrations. The former activity aimed at motivating system engineering topics through real world applications to give incoming freshman a higher level understanding of their degree. An eleven-week one-credit course was designed with hands-on projects in data analytics, design and manufacturing, operations research, and control systems. Surveys prior and post the activities revealed up to a 47% increase in interest towards systems engineering and design. The latter activity aimed at increasing the comfort levels of common robotics terms among high schoolers through soft robotics demonstration and hands-on activity. Soft robotics with its proximity to nature?s designs can be a more inclusive and relatable paradigm to study robotics terminologies. A soft robot activity from the popular soft robotics toolkit was designed for this purpose. While the study was inconclusive due to relatively smaller student size, certain core terms such as ?actuators? were better perceived through soft robotics than others such as feedback and controls.
